information:
Several airlines announced the resumption or launch of new flights to Beirut for the summer 2025 season. Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) is resuming service from Copenhagen and Stockholm in June. Emirates resumed its daily service from Dubai in February 2025 and added a second daily flight in April. Air France and its subsidiary Transavia also resumed flights from Paris in February. Other confirmed additions include a Wizz Air flight from Abu Dhabi starting June 4, a seasonal Middle East Airlines (MEA) route to Barcelona from June 26, and a LOT Polish Airlines flight from Warsaw beginning July 1, 2025.

According to airport statistics, Beirut International Airport handled 1,254,550 passengers in the first quarter of 2025, a 1.42% decrease from the same period in 2024. While passenger arrivals increased by 9.33%, departures fell by 11.60%, and the number of transit passengers dropped by over 92%. The Lebanese government has also implemented new security measures at the airport to combat smuggling, including banning certain Iranian flights and increasing security checks.

As of May 2025, the number of active destinations was estimated to be around 39, based on OAG schedule data, down from 53 in May 2024. A number of airlines that suspended routes in October 2023, including British Airways, Lufthansa Group, Saudia, EgyptAir, and Pegasus, had not fully returned. Key Gulf carriers like Kuwait Airways and Qatar Airways also remained absent. Lebanon’s tourism ministry has projected that summer arrivals for 2025 will be 30% below 2019 levels.

forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Security situation on the Israel–Lebanon front remains tense; insurers keep restrictions; only the already-announced resumptions (e.g., SAS CPH/ARN, Wizz AUH, MEA BCN, LOT WAW) materialize, with few or no additional Gulf/Turkish/Egyptian resumptions. Net count sits in the mid-40s on flightsfrom.com.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Clear de-escalation and insurer greenlights prompt several big resumptions in June: at least 7–10 net new destinations arrive quickly (e.g., Qatar Airways to DOH, Kuwait Airways to KWI, Saudia to RUH/JED, EgyptAir to CAI, Turkish or Pegasus to IST/SAW, Gulf Air to BAH) alongside MEA’s added seasonal European leisure routes, lifting the total above 51 by July 1.
forecast.rationale:
- What it would take: The research assistant (RA) reports ~39 active destinations in May 2025 (OAG), down from 53 in May 2024. To resolve Yes (>51), Beirut (BEY) needs roughly +13 versus May. The known pipeline adds about five by July 1: SAS (CPH, ARN), Wizz (AUH), MEA seasonal (BCN), LOT (WAW). That implies around 44 absent further changes.
- Missing pieces: Several key carriers/routes remain suspended as of May (RA: British Airways, Lufthansa Group, Saudia, EgyptAir, Pegasus; also Kuwait Airways and Qatar Airways). These represent many of the easiest incremental destinations needed to clear 51. With ongoing cross-border hostilities, high insurance premiums, and weak demand signals (tourism ministry projects summer arrivals ~30% below 2019; Q1 2025 pax down 1.4% YoY; transit down >90%), a broad wave of resumptions in the next six weeks looks unlikely.
- Countervailing updates: Positives include Emirates’ full resumption (and extra frequency) and Air France/Transavia returns, plus the named adds for June/July. But these mainly boost frequency and a handful of destinations, not the dozen-plus needed. New airport security measures and bans on some Iranian flights could even reduce destinations at the margin.
- Why not higher: From an estimated ~39 in May, the firm pipeline likely gets BEY to the low-to-mid 40s by July 1. Surging past 51 would require multiple major Gulf/Turkish/Egyptian resumptions plus additional MEA seasonal Europe leisure adds—an aggressive swing given the present risk and demand backdrop.
- Why not lower: Summer seasonality and already-announced launches provide real upside versus May. Airlines can announce short-notice resumptions if risk perception improves. A handful of additional returns (e.g., Turkish or Qatar) are plausible, even if not my base case.
- What would raise my forecast: Credible airline schedule filings and official notices (and appearance on flightsfrom.com) of two or more among Qatar (DOH), Kuwait (KWI), Saudia (JED/RUH), EgyptAir (CAI), Turkish/Pegasus (IST/SAW), Gulf Air (BAH) by mid-June; evidence of multiple MEA seasonal European additions beyond BCN.
- What would lower it: Further escalation or airspace/insurance issues leading to cancellations; continued absence of key Gulf and Turkish carriers into late June; any additional bans impacting Iranian or regional routes.
Taking the slow-to-change status quo seriously, I expect a total well under 52 by July 1 unless there’s a notable de-escalation-driven wave of resumptions in the next few weeks.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will there be greater than 51 direct flight destinations from Beirut, Lebanon on July 1, 2025?

Question background:
Catholic News Agency: [Lebanon will soon have its own ‘camino,’ once traveled by Christ and the Romans](https://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/263055/caminos-lebanon-new-initiative-is-designed-to-revive-religious-tourism-in-the-country) | Travel and Tour World: [Lebanon’s Hospitality Sector In Peril: Rising Costs And Low Tourism Threaten Survival](https://www.travelandtourworld.com/news/article/lebanons-hospitality-sector-in-peril-rising-costs-and-low-tourism-threaten-survival/) | The New Arab: [Summer canceIled: Israeli attack hits Lebanon tourism hopes](https://www.newarab.com/news/summer-canceiled-israeli-attack-hits-lebanon-tourism-hopes)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if there are greater than 51 direct flight destinations listed at the [All scheduled direct (non-stop) flights from Beirut (BEY)](https://www.flightsfrom.com/BEY) tracker when checked by Metaculus on or after July 1, 2025.




Your research assistant's report says:
Several airlines announced the resumption or launch of new flights to Beirut for the summer 2025 season. Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) is resuming service from Copenhagen and Stockholm in June. Emirates resumed its daily service from Dubai in February 2025 and added a second daily flight in April. Air France and its subsidiary Transavia also resumed flights from Paris in February. Other confirmed additions include a Wizz Air flight from Abu Dhabi starting June 4, a seasonal Middle East Airlines (MEA) route to Barcelona from June 26, and a LOT Polish Airlines flight from Warsaw beginning July 1, 2025.

According to airport statistics, Beirut International Airport handled 1,254,550 passengers in the first quarter of 2025, a 1.42% decrease from the same period in 2024. While passenger arrivals increased by 9.33%, departures fell by 11.60%, and the number of transit passengers dropped by over 92%. The Lebanese government has also implemented new security measures at the airport to combat smuggling, including banning certain Iranian flights and increasing security checks.

As of May 2025, the number of active destinations was estimated to be around 39, based on OAG schedule data, down from 53 in May 2024. A number of airlines that suspended routes in October 2023, including British Airways, Lufthansa Group, Saudia, EgyptAir, and Pegasus, had not fully returned. Key Gulf carriers like Kuwait Airways and Qatar Airways also remained absent. Lebanon’s tourism ministry has projected that summer arrivals for 2025 will be 30% below 2019 levels.

Today is 2025-05-21.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
